awd_titl_txt: Defining the architecture of the Pyk2 activation complex
awd_abstract_narration:
Neurons communicate with neighboring neurons through synaptic connections. This neuronal 'wiring' can change and adapt over time. Many aspects of the mechanisms controlling the changes in neuronal connections remain enigmatic. Nevertheless, the ability to strengthen and weaken neuron connections is critically important because this rewiring is linked to learning and memory formation. Each synaptic connection hosts a large collection of proteins poised to interpret patterns of neuronal communication. This research project seeks to discover how one team of proteins responds to synaptic activity to signal for synaptic changes. The central hub of the signaling team is Pyk2, a protein kinase. Pyk2 activates by rearranging its structure to form a large signaling assembly with associated signaling factors. The goal of this research is to determine the architecture of the Pyk2 signaling assembly. Understanding the assembly and activation of the Pyk2 signaling team will yield insights into how neuronal rewiring is initiated at the molecular scale. This proposal will train graduate and undergraduate students by using a team-based concept where graduate and undergraduate students will have an advisor/advisee relationship.

The objectives of this project are to reveal the molecular mechanisms of Pyk2 signaling linking post-synaptic Ca2+ influx to the Src cascades that tune synaptic plasticity. Illuminating the architecture of scaffolded signaling complexes remains a frontier goal in understanding synaptic plasticity. However, multi-protein signaling complexes are typically large and highly dynamic, challenging targets for structural characterization. While structures have been determined for isolated pieces of the signaling effectors, a critical question remains: how do the pieces assemble into functional signaling complexes? This project employs several strategies to dissect the activational signaling complex of the Pyk2 non-receptor tyrosine kinase. By leveraging hydrogen/deuterium exchange mass spectrometry, protein interactions and conformational changes will be mapped. Single particle electron microscopy will illuminate the overall shape of the activation complex. These approaches are amenable to describing heterogeneous ensembles of accessible conformers and architectures. Structural restraints derived by the complementary biophysical approaches will be integrated to build a model of the higher-order architecture of the signaling complex responsible for activating Pyk2. This project is supported by the Molecular Biophysics Cluster of the Molecular and Cellular Biosciences Division in the Biological Sciences Directorate.

por.por_cntn:
Squads of signaling proteins are responsible for tuning neuronal connections in the central nervous system. Neurons communicate across synapses, and a collection of richly organized signaling proteins respond and adapt to the frequency and strength of neuronal stimulation. The communication mechanisms of synaptic signaling proteins are the molecular foundations of learning and memory. This project focused on the signaling mechanisms of Py2k, a synaptic protein kinase that communicates via two main mechanisms: modifying signaling partners with phosphate and serving as a scaffold to unite teams of signaling proteins for cooperative functions. In addition, Pyk2 emerged as a gene duplication of an older kinase, FAK. As such, Pyk2 serves as an illuminating exemplar for how redundant proteins can evolve specialized functions in new cellular contexts.

Scientific Outcomes: To investigate the molecular interactions and movements underlying Pyk2 function, we employed diverse biophysical tools and chemical probes. We reconstituted purified Pyk2 and signaling partner proteins to trace the progression of the Pyk2 signaling response from a dormant, inactive state to a multiprotein scaffolded activation complex. Our results defined key protein interaction surfaces and dynamic motions responsible for the assembly of an activation complex composed of Pyk2, a scaffolding protein, and the central kinase Src. Integrating information about structure and dynamics from multiple experimental approaches allowed us to build a model of the higher-order signaling complex in action. Our models indicate that Pyk2 activation shares core mechanisms with the parent kinase FAK. However, key regulatory surfaces have been repurposed to respond to scaffolding interactions and novel stimuli.

Educational Outcomes: The scientific mission is founded on teams of researchers solving problems, generating new models, and testing ideas. Fostering the development of team-based problem-solving skills can empower the next generation of researchers. A major educational aim of this project was to develop, implement, and assess team-based mentoring in a first-year Biochemistry Learning Community (LC). The LC introduces new Biochemistry majors to university structures, academic planning, undergraduate research, science communication, and career exploration. We introduced a team-based approach to our LC with small groups of new students meeting weekly with two peer mentors. Outcomes assessment over five years revealed markedly increased student participation and engagement. The team-based approach also fostered a broadened LC mission, as peer mentors could be nimble and responsive to direct student feedback and interests. The LC encouraged early engagement in student research, and this project supported undergraduate teams jointly pursuing independent research on signaling mechanisms. Ultimately, the new team-based LC approach supported over 280 first-year biochemistry students and launched seven student teams into multi-year research projects.
